This effort demonstrates America’s commitment to human rights around the world. The US must, and no doubt will, exert the moral leadership necessary to help Uyghurs right now.

This bill identifies Uyghurs+other ethnic minorities facing persecution by the Chinese gov. as Priority 2 Refugees, which designates them for special humanitarian concern to the US, makes them eligible for resettlement processing, & expedites the visa process for Uyghur refugees

Reports from Xinjiang describe a systematic program by the Chinese government involving the arbitrary detention of more than 1 million Uyghurs, torture, forced sterilization, sexual assault, beatings, food deprivation,& the denial of religious, cultural, & linguistic freedoms.
China is committing crimes against humanity in its efforts to persecute and repress the Uyghurs and other predominantly Muslim ethnic minorities in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous region.

The US has a proud history of welcoming oppressed peoples from around the world. 

Following that tradition, I’m glad the House passed the America COMPETES Act, which includes my Uyghur Human Rights Protection Act, to expedite refugee processing for persecuted Uyghurs.

As Israel expands & deepens its relations with nations in the region and beyond, these efforts to delegitimize the one Jewish state in the world will fail. 

Israel’s allies will not abandon our commitment to Israel’s security. And the U.S. will continue to stand w/ our ally.

Most shocking of all is that this report appears to question Israel’s founding in 1948 as a modern Jewish state, ignore Israel’s entire history, and even question the legitimacy of the state’s entire existence.
A nation where Arab & Jewish Israelis serve side-by-side in the same governing coalition in the Knesset.

This document recklessly paints the word 'apartheid' over the one true democracy in the Middle East; a nation w/ the most diverse governing coalition in its history, & more respect for women’s rights, LGBTQI+ rights, & rights of marginalized communities than any in the region.

Since the founding of the modern State of Israel, the world’s only Jewish state has faced no shortage of attacks.

This report is full of the same mischaracterizations, false accusations, & biased language that have been hurled at Israel & its advocates for decades.

Amnesty International labeled Israel an apartheid state in a report they issued earlier today.

Here’s my response:

Justice for survivors & their heirs, before time runs out, is critical.

"The act of remembering is our solemn obligation to those who perished. It must never become a passive activity."

Abortion access is being dismantled right now. Florida is getting ready to follow Texas’ lead with draconian laws of its own.

Our last hope is to #LiberateAbortion nationally. #AbortionIsEssential, and we need the Senate to pass the Women’s Health Protection Act now.

Whether or not Roe is overturned, the damage is done. What’s at stake is already happening in our country—women forced to carry dangerous, involuntary, or unwanted pregnancies to term because doctors are too afraid to provide the care they’re entitled to under the constitution.

6 week bans, 15 week, they are all the same: they’re taking a right AWAY from Americans: the right for people in this country, w/their healthcare providers, to make their own reproductive care decisions, instead of a state gov’t making it for them.

Abortion access isn't only a human right: it's a Constitutional right. Even so, the right to abortion has never been enough to guarantee access. And that’s true now more than ever.

For Texas, there is no #RoevWade anniversary tomorrow. For the rest of us, it could be the last.

I am eager to see the reform process unfold inclusively and urge President Saïed to seek consensus on Tunisia’s future with input from diverse political and civil society voices. (3/3)

I am closely monitoring the situation and remain concerned particularly since the timeline as announced continues to suspend parliament until after the next election slated for Dec. 2022. The Tunisian people want and deserve a transparent government by and for the people. (2/3)
I was pleased to see that Tunisian President Saïed finally announced a timeline outlining a path for political reform and parliamentary elections. (1/3)
All parties involved must remain committed to advancing these objectives and ensuring that presidential and parliamentary elections are conducted as soon as practicable. (5/5)
I support the decision to ensure elections are free and fair and urge all parties to support continued nonviolence and sustained dialogue. (4/5)

I acknowledge and appreciate the engagement of senior U.S. officials, including Special Envoy and Ambassador Richard Norland, along with UN Special Advisor Ms. Stephanie Williams and Libyan officials, civil society, and members of the international community. (3/5)

… under the current legal framework would lead to civil unrest.

The Libyan people overwhelmingly want to choose their next government and they have a right to do so in an environment free from violence and intimidation, and with a clearly defined legal framework. (2/5)

I'm proud of the progress the Libyan people have made to move their country towards national elections. 

Two weeks ago, the Libyan High National Election Commission postponed presidential elections slated for Dec. 24 due to broad agreement that holding elections... (1/5)

I also applaud @USAmbUN for pledging to push back on the council’s fixation on Israel, the one Jewish state in the world, that happens to also be the only nation with a permanent agenda item at the Human Rights Council. This, too, must change.

As @USAmbUN said yesterday: “We hold others to our own standard: while we may sometimes fall short of our own ideals, we must constantly strive to be as inclusive, rights respecting, and free as possible.” We must be able to expect the same commitment from all #UNHRC members.

Without a 2/3 majority, no enforceable mechanisms prevent human rights abusers from getting a seat at the table. That must change, and now is the time to take stock. In order to make meaningful, needed reforms, there must be standards for #UNHRC membership.

The Human Rights Council is the @UN body responsible for promoting and protecting global human rights, but it isn't made up of rights-respecting countries. Known human rights abusers - Russia, China, Venezuela and Cuba - have the responsibility to defend human rights!

Yesterday, the U.S. was re-elected to @UN_HRC. Human rights belong at the forefront of U.S. foreign policy.
